May it please your good L. Wheras her
M
tie
is informed,
as your l
re
doth signifiy of
e 9 of De
c
. W
c
I receaved three
dayes past,
t
some dealing hath bin used by
e
States
of
theses c
o
treis, to
suade w
t
e Provinces of
Brab
a
t
and
Flan-
ders
, up
o
this opportunitie of
e death of
e
Duke of Parma
,
to free their estate fr
o
e Spanish servitude, and to
cure
unto th
e
selves
e Pacification made at
Gaunt
, I doe
assure your L.
t
by order of
e States, there hath not any
thing bin done to any suche purpose. Onely this I
understand,
t
some privat
sones of themselves but yet
w
t
e privitie of
e Principal heere, have writt
e
to their
frindes
t
remaine in those quarters, to
t
effect
t
is re
q
red.
But those endevours are so slenders, as by
any
every
mans con-
jecture nothing will come of it. And where I
am willed by her Hig
es
if so be
t
e States have done
nothing therein, to
pose it unto them as fr
o
her, and
to shewe them her good liking, it may please you to
understande, as I have formerly signified,
t
e Deputies
of
e States are gone into their Provinces, and are not
like to meete againe, till
e ende of this moneth.
But in
e meane season I have moved
e mater to M
r
Barnevelt, and likewise to some others of
e chiefest
heere in place, who are all in a maner of one kinde of
judgem
t
,
t
before they goe in hand w
t
any such practise,
they must see some better ouverture. For although
they have intelligence,
t
e Enemies c
o
manders are at strife
among themselves, yet unlese it were more then is yet
understoode, they have found by ex
ience of former times
and like attemptes,
t
their l
re
s and messages have rather
reconciled those
t
were at discorde, then caused th
e
to
hearken to
t
w
c
was
posed. Nevertheles if they see
fol.2v
any hope to effect any good, whether it be for [that the]
Enemy is in greater disorder, or for other occasi[ons, they]
seeme to me to be as ready as can be desired. W[herupon]
I am resolved, assoone as
e States assemble ag[ain]
and according to
e occurrences
t
come fr
o
e Enemy [to de-]
liver
e opinion of her M
tie
unto them: w
c
yet [I think]
I shall be forced to c
o
municat unto some, and not[unto]
them all, in their g
na
l meeting. For they are [many]
in number, and of divers places, humours, and re[ligions]
so as hardly such a mater will be secretly car[ied,]
w
c
will make many men unwilling to be imployed [in an]
action so full of danger to themselves, and also to [their]
frindes, w
t
whome they must negotiat in
e Ene[mies]
c
o
trey. But for
e maner of my
posing and co[urse of]
ceeding, when
t
the time is for it heere, I wi[ll si-]
gnify w
at
I think for my privat c
o
ceat, I am fully [persuaded]
at for Brab
a
t and Flanders, or any other Province [that is]
under
e Enemy, unlese they seeke of themselves [to shake]
of
e yoke of
e Spanishe gouvernem
t
, they shall [not]
greatly be
voked by
e States of these c
o
treis. [I]
should but trouble your L. to signify all my re[asons]
but
t
w
c
moveth me most, is
e want
t
they have [of a]
sone of authority, by whome suche motions might [be made]
and directions given for good execution. For [though it]
seeme
t
Co
u
t Maurice
hath some
p
rogative in
t [respect]
as Governour g
na
l of all these Provinces, excepting [Friseland]
yet his chiefest c
o
mand is in military maters, and as [also that way]
so restrained, as of him selfe he can doe litle, but in [affairs]
of
e State
s
, no more then other magistrates: in w
c
[he dealeth]
very seldome, and as it seemeth very unwillingly. [For it]
fol.3r
is c
o
monly thought
t
of his naturall inclination he deliteth
not muche in
e maneging of suche causes, nor he hath no
man about him of speciall ex
ience, by whose advise he
may be steeded. And as for
e rest of
e States men
heere, though some be more able and carefull and forwarder
then others to
p
ferre a good motion, and to follow it effectually,
yet they are but very fewe, and of equal autoritie w
t
a
great many more, whereby they are forced in most occasi
o
s
to keepe
t
pase
t
others doe, and not to drawe them by
posals into newe kinde of actions. I could hold
your L. w
t
rehearsal of
others
other im
fections, w
c
are
so
great
many and so great in all
e courses of this go-
verment, as they leese very often very singular oppor-
tunities of bettering their condition. But this already
is more then needed to your L. in special, who hath heere
so many proofes of their weakenes in all thinges: w
c
yet
I thought in this sort to touche in a worde, to
e end yow
might
ceave,
t
there is no alteration in
e forme of their
ceeding, and
t
e apparance is but smalle,
t
they will
satisfy her M
tie
in
t
w
c
I am charged to participat unto
them.
And so I humbly take my leave. From
e
Hage. Ja
